vclaim: Neil Armstrong's space boots don't match a picture of his spot on the moon, suggesting that the moon landing was a trick.
date: stated on April 23, 2019 in a Facebook post:
title: No, these pictures of Neil Armstrong's space boots and the footprints don't disprove the moon's landing.
text: It's been almost 50 years since Neil Armstrong walked on the moon, yet conspiracy theories that the moon's landing was fake. "Did I miss something?" The image of the fingerprint in question was taken by astronaut Paz Aldrin and not Armstrong. According to a series of photographs on the lunar and planetary Institute website, it is a picture of the print of Aldrin, not Armstrong. The bottom of Aldrin's shoes and the footprint are identical. Armstrong left a similar trail at the same pace. According to Forbes 2017, Armstrong and Aldrin left about 100 tools, gear and garbage on the moon. "Nasa wanted the mission to bring as many moon rock and dust samples as possible," says the story, "which means that the crew needed to leave behind everything that actually didn't need a return trip to Earth." The conspiracy theories of the moon landing remain, but their first footprints on the moon continue. There is no wind to blow it up, according to NASA, and it will be there for a million years.
